title: 2 Simple Ways to Crop an Image Using GIMP

steps.title: Open GIMP.
steps.content: Open GIMP. GIMP has an icon that resembles a fox with a paintbrush in his mouth. If you haven't installed GIMP, go ahead and download GIMP and install it for free.

steps.title: Open an image.
steps.content: Open an image. You can do this by clicking File at the top, and then Open . Use the file navigator to find and select an image. Alternatively, you can open the image in GIMP by right-clicking the file on your computer, selecting Open With , and then GIMP .

steps.title: Click on the crop tool.
steps.content: Click on the crop tool. This looks like a precision (exacto) knife. You can find this in the Toolbox. [1] X Research source If you can't find the tool, you can click Tools > Transform Tools > Crop in the image window. When this tool is selected, your cursor will change.

steps.title: Drag a square around the portion of the image you want to keep.
steps.content: Drag a square around the portion of the image you want to keep. This creates a rectangle around the image section. The dark area outside the square is the area that will be cropped.

steps.title: Adjust the cropping rectangle.
steps.content: Adjust the cropping rectangle. To adjust the size of the cropping rectangle, click and drag any of the squares in the four corners. If you want to use guides, click View in the menu bar, then click the box next to "Show Guides". This displays rulers to the top and left of the image.

steps.title: Double-click the area inside the rectangle.
steps.content: Double-click the area inside the rectangle. This crops your image and removes the dark area outside the rectangle. If you want to save your image, click File , and then Save . To save the image as a separate file, click Save As in the drop-down menu, and then type a name for the image and click Save .

steps.title: Open an image in GIMP.
steps.content: Open an image in GIMP. You can do this by clicking File at the top, and then Open . Use the file navigator to find and select an image. Alternatively, you can open the image in GIMP by right-clicking the file on your computer, selecting Open With , and then GIMP .

steps.title: Click the Selection tool.
steps.content: Click the Selection tool. It's one of the two icons that resembles a rectangle or an oval with a dotted line around it. You can find this in the Toolbox. Use the rectangle selection tool to create a rectangle selection. Use the oval selection tool to create a round selection.

steps.title: Select the area you want to keep.
steps.content: Select the area you want to keep. To do this, click and drag your cursor from one corner of the section to the opposite corner. This creates a rectangle with a dotted line inside around the selected area.

steps.title: Adjust the selected area.
steps.content: Adjust the selected area. You can adjust the selected area by clicking and dragging any of the squares in the four corners.

steps.title: Click Image.
steps.content: Click Image . It's in the menu bar at the top of the screen. This displays a drop-down menu.

steps.title: Click Crop to Selection.
steps.content: Click Crop to Selection . It's in the menu bar below "Image". This removes everything except the area inside your selection. If you want to save your image, click File , and then Save . To save the image as a separate file, click Save As in the drop-down menu, and then type a name for the image and click Save .
